author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic Space Plane Flight: How to Watch
description: The V.S.S. Unity will lift off from New Mexico on Sunday morning as billionaire entrepreneurs race to make spaceflight unexceptional.
content: Richard Branson is finally getting his trip to space on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar
title: Egypt Denies Times Report That Officials Sexually Abused Women
description: The government rejected the accounts of women who said they were sexually assaulted by Egyptian security and justice officials during searches.
content: CAIRO — The Egyptian government has denied a report by The New York Times that women who encounter the country’s justice system risk sexual abuse during searches by state authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘M-u-r-r-a-y-a’ Earns 14-Year-Old $50,000 and a Place in History
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 10, 2021.
content: “It’s like asking a millipede how they walk with all those legs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Haitian officials called for U.S. military assistance. Some Haitians say, ‘No, No & No.’
description: Intellectuals, activists and others say the country needs to find a solution on its own, and that international intervention has damaged their country.
content: Intellectuals and members of Haiti’s civil society quickly criticized a call by Haitian officials for the United States to send in troops, citing earlier interventions by foreign powers and international organizations that further destabilized Haiti and left a trail of abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Thomas Cleary, Prolific Translator of Eastern Texts, Dies at 72
description: His renderings of classic works of Buddhism, Taoism and more brought them to a general Western readership.
content: Thomas Cleary, who translated scores of Buddhist, Taoist, ancient Chinese and other texts into English, greatly broadening access to these works in the West, died on June 20 in Oakland, Calif. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China Plans Security Checks for Tech Companies Listing Overseas
description: The proposed rules would close a gap that let the ride-hailing company Didi go public on Wall Street before assuring Beijing that its data was safe.
content: China moved on Saturday toward requiring domestic tech companies to submit to a cybersecurity checkup before they can go public on overseas stock exchanges, a step that would close the regulatory gap that allowed the ride-hailing giant Didi to list shares on Wall Street last week without getting a clean bill of digital health from Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Passive-Aggressive Tactic
description: With Trenton Charlson in the spotlight, the crowd roars.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Is it Christmas in July? Trenton Charlson has come down the chimney with his 30th puzzle for The New York Times, and Caitlin Lovinger is taking a well-deserved weekend off, so my stocking is overflowing. I have the distinct privilege of bashing my brain repeatedly against Mr. Charlson’s devilish clues and then writing about the experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Cannes Film Festival: The Director of ‘Showgirls’ Takes on Lesbian Nuns
description: Paul Verhoeven defends “Benedetta,” which is based on a nonfiction book and set in the 17th century: “I don’t really understand how you can blaspheme about something that happened.”
content: CANNES, France — Forgive them, Father, for they have sinned. Repeatedly! Creatively! And wait until you hear what they did with that Virgin Mary statuette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Texas Man Who Waited Hours to Vote Is Arrested on Charges of Illegal Voting
description: Hervis Rogers was ineligible to cast a ballot in the 2020 presidential primary because he was still on parole, according to the state’s attorney general. He now faces four decades in prison.
content: A 62-year-old Texas man who waited hours to cast a ballot in last year’s presidential primary was arrested this week on charges that he had voted illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quick and Easy Grilling
description: Ali Slagle’s smart recipes skip the marinades but not the flavor.
content: Gas up the grill! Ali Slagle’s guide to fast, delicious grilling produced some of the most popular recipes on New York Times Cooking this week. Whether you make her spicy citrus skirt steak (above), spiced grilled halloumi or chicken with parsley-olive sauce, you’re sure to end up with a flavorful dinner that doesn’t require a lengthy marinade. Or try something else from our collection of quick and easy grilling recipes. For a dessert and cocktail in one, follow up your meal with Vaughn Vreeland’s salted margarita bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Hughes
title: Is It Art? You May Have to Ask a Neanderthal Critic.
description: A bone to pick from Germany’s Unicorn Cave. Plus fireflies in sync, peer review in crisis and China’s astronauts at work in their spacesuits.
content: In 2019, a team of archaeologists climbed a steep, rocky hill in central Germany and burrowed inside the collapsed entrance of the Unicorn Cave, named as such because people in the Middle Ages once scoured it for unicorn bones. Today it is famous for its animal fossils.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: To Kill a Swan? Dispute Over a Bird’s Fate Ends With a Twist.
description: A mute swan, beloved by some, was set to be euthanized after wildlife officials deemed him dangerously aggressive. Then something unexpected happened.
content: When Friday began, Alfie the swan was on an avian version of death row. By the time evening came, it seemed he had won a reprieve — though not through the efforts of the people who were trying to save him or the government agencies they had pleaded with for help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Heat Wave Spread Fire That ‘Erased’ Canadian Town
description: Busloads of residents went to tour the charred town of Lytton, British Columbia, this week and found it almost unrecognizable.
content: TORONTO — Something strange was happening to the acacia trees in Lytton, British Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Colombian accused in assassination plot told sister he was there to protect, not to kill.
description: His message came shortly before he died himself in the bloody aftermath of the assassination.
content: The sister of the one of the Colombians accused in the plot to assassinate President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti said he told her that he had not gone to Haiti to kill anyone — but rather had traveled to the Caribbean nation after receiving a job offer to protect a “very important person.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Haunani-Kay Trask, Champion of Native Rights in Hawaii, Dies at 71
description: She helped found the field of Hawaiian studies and pressed for Indigenous sovereignty. “We will die as Hawaiians,” she said. “We will never be Americans.”
content: Haunani-Kay Trask, a scholar, poet and champion of sovereignty for the Hawaiian people who decried what she called the colonization and despoliation of her native land, died on July 3 in Honolulu. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Investigating a Building Collapse by Studying Clues From One Still Standing
description: An expert called upon after the 9/11 attacks and the Oklahoma City bombing is now examining the Champlain Towers North in Surfside, Fla., to discover why its sister building collapsed.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Pavers around the Champlain Towers North swimming pool have been yanked up and drywall removed from a few condo hallways and closets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Agence France-Presse
title: Car Bomb Targeting Somali Police Kills at Least 5
description: The attack in Mogadishu was claimed by Al Shabab, the Qaeda-linked Islamist group that has carried out waves of attacks in an effort to topple the government.
content: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A large car bomb targeting a prominent police official exploded on Saturday in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, killing at least five people, the police and witnesses said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Grant
title: There’s a Specific Kind of Joy We’ve Been Missing
description: We find our greatest bliss in moments of “collective effervescence.”
content: In late June, over 15,000 vaccinated people packed in to watch the Foo Fighters reopen Madison Square Garden. When the band brought the comedian Dave Chappelle onstage to sing the Radiohead song “Creep,” the audience erupted in the closest thing I’ve seen to rapture in a solid year and a half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: When a No-Pet Policy Isn’t Really a No-Pet Policy
description: Pet policies are not always as straightforward as they seem. Sometimes they apply to some tenants but not others in the same building.
content: Q: I used to love my rent-stabilized apartment, where I’ve lived for a decade, until building management relaxed its strict no-pet policy. I have severe allergies and prefer not to live with other people’s pets. Suddenly, everyone has a dog. Despite my complaints about barking and dog hair trapped in the laundry machines, management insists that the building is not pet friendly. At this point, I’d like to move, but I just signed another two-year lease. Can I break my lease over the weakened pet policy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Privacy Is Still a Victim When Rape Cases Hit the Justice System
description: Britain is struggling to end its dependence on the traumatizing seizure of data from victims’ phones. Pervasive rape culture is making it difficult.
content: Things were supposed to be different this time, Brooke thought in disbelief as the police officer demanded that she hand over every scrap of data on her phone to investigators — not because she was suspected of a crime, but because she was the victim of one. Years earlier, a man who Brooke had until then considered a friend pulled her into a London alley, pushed her against a wall, choked her and violently sexually assaulted her. Her fear and humiliation, more than just the invasion of her body, seemed to be his goal. Several times, she said, she broke free, only to have him catch her, throw her back against the wall, and assault her again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: In New Hampshire, a Low-Key Democrat May Face a High-Profile Fight
description: Senator Maggie Hassan, a former governor of her state, is working to burnish her centrist image without making political waves.
content: MEREDITH, N.H. — At the Twin Barns Brewing Co., perched near the shoreline of Lake Winnipesaukee, Senator Maggie Hassan sampled some of the signature product on a recent afternoon, then chased it with a promise to fight for more reliable internet service, which the owners said they needed to maintain their customer base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Ashleigh Barty Wins Wimbledon Women’s Singles Title
description: The world No. 1 and tournament favorite fended off Karolina Pliskova in three sets to win her first Wimbledon title.
content: Ashleigh Barty won her first Wimbledon singles title Saturday, beating Karolina Pliskova, 6-3, 6-7(4), 6-3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Donald Trump will attend the fight, Dana White said.
description: The third fight between Conor McGregor and Dustin Poirier is expected to be one of the biggest sporting events of the year, and perhaps just as alluring as the fight itself is the spectacle of celebrities expected to be in attendance to watch two of the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s biggest stars face off.
content: The third fight between Conor McGregor and Dustin Poirier is expected to be one of the biggest sporting events of the year, and perhaps just as alluring as the fight itself is the spectacle of celebrities expected to be in attendance to watch two of the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s biggest stars face off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Daniel Raymon, I think I’m in love. Bring on more PandAs, please.
content: This Sunday, I’m picking up the Variety column for the first time, filling in for Caitlin Lovinger. I was a little apprehensive about unzipping the advance file of puzzles, not knowing what I would find. Inside, was a brand of brainteaser that I had not solved before: a PandA, or Puns and Anagrams puzzle. PandAs, where have you been all my life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: Road Rage, ‘Zipper Merging’ and a Stress-Free Path Through Traffic
description: Experts love the zipper merge, but drivers are just as likely to see it as others rudely cutting their turn in line.
content: You’re approaching a construction zone and a sign tells you the left lane will end several miles ahead. Traffic is heavy, but you see an opening and move to the right lane. As you inch along, drivers to your left keep zipping by. Miles ahead, you finally reach the merge point and the left-lane drivers make their move. Your pulse quickens. You pull up tight on the car in front of you and refuse to let anyone in. Are you in the right, or are you fortunate that nothing escalated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Dana Rubinstein and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Eric Adams Has Plans for New York, Beyond Public Safety
description: Mr. Adams, the Democratic mayoral nominee, has stances on policing, transportation and education that suggest a shift from Mayor Bill de Blasio.
content: In the afterglow of winning the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York City, Eric Adams began to set out his mission if elected in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Craig and Sophie Kasakove
title: Death Valley Hits 130 Degrees as Heat Wave Sweeps the West
description: Temperatures were broiling from Utah to California as another “heat dome” led Western states to set up cooling centers and issue motel vouchers.
content: FURNACE CREEK, Calif. — For Gary Bryant, the tenth-of-a-mile walk from his modular home to the air-conditioned restaurant where he was working on Saturday was “quite enough” time outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: Britney Spears’s Case Calls Attention to Wider Questions on Guardianship
description: Legal oversight arrangements are seen as protection for some, but advocates for people with disabilities question the need for them in many cases.
content: For nearly 13 years, Ryan King was under a guardianship not unlike the legal conservatorship that controls Britney Spears’s life and finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: The Eclectic Lives BehindAlice Neel’s Portraits
description: She painted her friends and lovers, as well as well-known artists, activists, critics and scholars.
content: My introduction to the painter Alice Neel was a screen print that hung on the living room wall of my grandparents’ home in Woodstock, N.Y. — a provocative portrait of Neel’s pouting granddaughter lounging on a striped chair. That portrait then moved within my family, to Minneapolis, San Francisco and, finally, to my apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan — down the street from where Neel painted and lived —  where it now hangs on my wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: ‘Mother, When Will You Come?’: The Covid Orphans of India
description: Thousands of children lost their parents during a calamitous wave of infections. While the government is vowing to help them, many face the risk of neglect and exploitation when the attention fades.
content: PATTAPUR, India — In a small, colorfully painted house on India’s eastern coast, G. Sonali Reddy cooks meals and feeds her younger siblings by day and rocks them to sleep at night, hoping to assuage their fears, just as her mother would.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Here’s how to watch and stream the fight.
description: The third fight between McGregor and Poirier could be the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s biggest spectacle of the year.
content: U.F.C. 264 takes place Saturday night at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas. The early preliminary fights start at 6 p.m. Eastern, and the main pay-per-view card will begin at 10 p.m. McGregor and Poirier most likely will not fight until around midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: On This German Farm, Cows Are in Charge. Or at Least Coequals.
description: The cows don’t have to produce milk. The pigs sleep late. No animal on this former dairy farm serves a human need. Their only purpose is to live peacefully — and provoke questions about how we eat.
content: BUTJADINGEN, Germany — Tom will lay his head in the lap of anyone who sits down to rub his neck, while Tilda prefers just to nuzzle her young son. Cuddles aren’t really Chaya’s thing, but if she’s in the mood, she’ll play pugnaciously with a bale of hay as if it’s a giant ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Falling for Couture’s Gravitational Pull
description: Everything you need to know from the first post-pandemic in-person couture week, including the biggest debut, most viral moments and non-influencer trends.
content: PARIS — The Cannes Film Festival is in starlet red-carpet swing; the billionaires are back in Sun Valley; and in Paris — “It’s like a school reunion, no?” said Carine Roitfeld, the French fashion editor, flicking her veil of hair from her black-lined eyes and glancing around the Dior show on Monday as the first live couture week in more than a year began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Does Free College Work?
description: President Biden’s $109 billion plan for free community college would be similar to existing programs in states such as Tennessee.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Certain Bridge Positions
description: Ashish Vengsarkar extracts maximum humor from his captive audience.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — In his puzzle this week, Ashish Vengsarkar leaps across decades of pop culture tropes, playing crack-the-whip with solvers. Shamelessly, he drags us along hand-in-hand behind him down the chutes and up the ladders of dad joke territory, enticing us onward through a thicket of puns by dropping occasional amuse-gueules of ethnic food at strategic points on our route.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Catherine Porter
title: Haiti’s Power Vacuum Escalates Kingmakers’ Battle for Control
description: The contest for power is taking place on two levels. One battle pits current politicians against one another; the other is among power brokers vying for control behind the scenes.
content: The assassination of Haiti’s president has thrown the nation into disarray, spawned shootouts on the streets and left terrified citizens cowering in their homes. But behind the scenes a bigger, high-stakes battle for control of the country is already accelerating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: After Years as a Battleground, Investment Boom Lifts Iraqi City
description: Ramadi was the site of some of the fiercest fighting against U.S. troops during the Iraq war, then came a devastating fight with ISIS. Now, it’s emerging as one of Iraq’s most stable cities.
content: RAMADI, Iraq — On the banks of the Euphrates River, the iron beams and bricks are going up for a 20-story luxury hotel with swimming pools, a spa, and restaurants jutting out into the blue-green waters at the edge of the Iraqi city of Ramadi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: At Wimbledon, Men’s Final Takes a Back Seat to England vs. Italy
description: In London, Novak Djokovic’s attempt at a 20th Grand Slam title on Sunday is but an opening act for the European Championship match starring England and Italy.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Elizabeth Wright, a lawyer from Stratford-upon-Avon, was enjoying her fourth day at Wimbledon on Friday as she watched the first men’s semifinal on a large screen. A strawberry floated in her glass of prosecco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Global Tax Overhaul Gains Steam as G20 Backs New Levies
description: The approach marks a reversal of years of economic policies that embraced low taxes as a way for countries to attract investment and fuel growth.
content: VENICE — Global leaders on Saturday agreed to move ahead with what would be the most significant overhaul of the international tax system in decades, with finance ministers from the world’s 20 largest economies backing a proposal that would crack down on tax havens and impose new levies on large, profitable multinational companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: With Wimbledon Win, Ashleigh Barty Continues Mentor’s Work
description: The top women’s player has long felt a deep connection with fellow Indigenous Australian Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who won her first Wimbledon singles title in 1971.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Long before Ashleigh Barty became a Wimbledon champion, Evonne Goolagong Cawley believed Barty could be a Wimbledon champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Would You Get a ‘Pandemic Tattoo’?
description: While many people are eager to put the ravages of Covid-19 behind them, some prefer to be reminded forever.
content: Every day during lockdown Samantha Barry, the editor of Glamour Magazine, walked or ran along the West Side Highway in New York City. “I would go from Chelsea to the Statue of Liberty,” she said. “This was my moment of sanity every day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: A Case for Patriotic Education
description: Americans should learn the whole truth about our history. But it still makes sense to start with heroism and inspiration.
content: I have my doubts about America. As a Catholic, my first loyalty is to a faith that predates and promises to outlast our Republic, that was disfavored for much of our history and may be headed into disfavor once again. American anti-Catholicism is far from the worst evil in this nation’s history, but it still instills a special obligation to take critiques of our Anglo-liberal-Protestant inheritance seriously, whether they come from radicals or traditionalists or both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: Biden Warns Putin to Act Against Ransomware Groups, or U.S. Will Strike Back
description: Mr. Biden’s phone call appeared to be a pointed ultimatum to stop the hackers, who have attacked computer networks in the United States with relative impunity.
content: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday that time was running out for him to rein in the ransomware groups striking the United States, telegraphing that this could be Mr. Putin’s final chance to take action on Russia’s harboring of cybercriminals before the United States moved to dismantle the threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: In Wimbledon Loss, Karolina Pliskova Sees a Silver Lining
description: The former world No. 1 may have lost to Ashleigh Barty, but she takes the value of learning to cope with falling short as a critical part of learning how to win.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Karolina Pliskova was happy with how she had played in the Wimbledon final on Saturday, despite a disastrous start — she lost the first 14 points of the match — and the fact that it ended in a 6-3, 6-7 (4), 6-3 loss to Ashleigh Barty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: How the White Press Wrote Off Black America
description: News organizations are belatedly apologizing for racist journalism that alienated generations of  African-Americans
content: Newspapers that championed white supremacy throughout the pre-civil rights South paved the way for lynching by declaring African Americans nonpersons. They embraced the language once used at slave auctions by denying Black citizens the courtesy titles Mr. and Mrs. and referring to them in news stories as “the negro,” “the negress” or “the nigger.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Catherine Porter
title: Who Paid for That Mansion? A Senator or the Haitian People?
description: Valued at $3.4 million, a Haitian senator’s Montreal villa has become a potent emblem of the growing gap between Haiti’s impoverished citizens and its wealthy political elite.
content: MONTREAL — He is one of the few lawmakers left in Haiti, a close ally of the assassinated president who has kept his seat while the country’s democratic institutions have been whittled away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
title: Jehan Sadat, 87, Widow of Egypt’s President and Women’s Advocate, Dies
description: Until her husband was assassinated in 1981, she pushed him to enact measures aimed at improving women’s rights and education.
content: CAIRO — Jehan Sadat, the widow of former President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, whom she pushed to enact a series of measures aimed at improving women’s rights, died on Friday in Cairo. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Sorry, We Aren’t Going Back to the Movies
description: The pandemic forced Hollywood to fully embrace the home-theater experience, leaving struggling cine in the dust.
content: I love Vin Diesel so much that he is the only man who could persuade me to head back to the movie theater post-Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: The Big Question of the 2022 Midterms: How Will the Suburbs Swing?
description: Democrats and Republicans are already jockeying for a crucial voting bloc that soured on Donald Trump, tilted to Joe Biden and now holds the key to the second half of the president’s term.
content: PAPILLION, Neb. — Pursuing a bipartisan infrastructure deal and trumpeting a revived economy and progress against the pandemic, President Biden is trying to persuade the nation that Democrats are the party that gets things done. His message is aimed at holding on to a set of voters in next year’s midterms who could determine the fate of his agenda: suburbanites who abandoned former President Donald Trump in droves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: After Walkout, Texas Voting Showdown Part II Looms
description: The Texas Legislature is trying again after Democrats staged an abrupt walkout in May to kill a Republican plan narrowing voting options in the state.
content: AUSTIN — The issues and arguments were familiar, but the road ahead revolved around a more novel question as nearly 100 witnesses lined a Capitol hallway awaiting the start of an 8 a.m. committee hearing on voting rights in Texas: Do Democrats have a second act?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: In Sri Lanka, the Government Looks Increasingly Like a Family Firm
description: Three brothers of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa now hold top posts in his government. Two of his nephews have official positions, too.
content: The first attempt by a Rajapaksa to return to power in Sri Lanka was brief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman and Kellen Browning
title: Are We in the Metaverse Yet?
description: Crypto people say they’re building it. Gamers might already be living in it. The art world is cashing in on it. Web veterans are trying to save it. But what is it?
content: The biggest ideas in tech often lurch into the lexicon before they are truly coherent. Jargon appears out of nowhere, underexplained and overused: the internet of things, the sharing economy, the cloud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Athan Theoharis, Chronicler of F.B.I. Abuses, Dies at 84
description: He found his way through the formerly unobtainable files of J. Edgar Hoover, whom he called “an insubordinate bureaucrat in charge of a lawless organization.”
content: Athan Theoharis, a pre-eminent historian of the F.B.I. whose indefatigable research into the agency’s formerly unobtainable files produced revelations about decades of civil liberties abuses under the leadership of J. Edgar Hoover, died on July 3 at his home in Syracuse, N.Y. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Suns Have Gone Old School at Center. It’s Working.
description: The center matchup between Milwaukee’s Brook Lopez and Phoenix’s Deandre Ayton is pitting two eras of basketball against each other.
content: There is a clash of styles at the center position in the N.B.A. finals between the Phoenix Suns and the Milwaukee Bucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Michael D. Shear and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Administration Shows Little Appetite for Haiti’s Troop Request
description: Pentagon officials noted that the request was broad and did not specify the number or types of forces needed.
content: WASHINGTON — Haiti’s request for U.S. troops to help stabilize the country following the assassination of its president presents a difficult choice for President Biden: send forces to aid a neighbor even as he is trying to pare down America’s military footprint overseas, or refrain and risk allowing the chaos unfolding there to escalate into a refugee crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Ascension of Bernie Sanders
description: The senator is willing to break a few eggs, over easy, to get Democrats back on track to their working-class roots.
content: BURLINGTON, Vt. — I want to talk to Bernie about Balenciaga. And Britney. And Dua Lipa, Sha’Carri Richardson and Joe Manchin’s houseboat. And whether he prefers red or white horseradish on his gefilte fish. And the state of capitalism, and the absurd price of a Birkin bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrice Peck
title: Hiring, Firing, Setting the Culture: Black Women at the Top of TV News
description: The book, ‘Ladies Leading,’ shines a spotlight on the highest ranking Black women in television news management. But even at the top, sexism and racism abound.
content: — Ava Thompson Greenwell, the author of “Ladies Leading: The Black Women Who Control Television News”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Cernansky
title: In Indigenous Knowledge, Innovative Solutions
description: The scientific method is designed to be indifferent to morals or values, but  “Indigenous knowledge puts them back in.”
content: Nearly two decades ago, when the New Zealand highway authority was planning the Waikato Expressway, people from the Māori tribe Ngāti Naho objected. The highway would encroach on an area that, in Māori tradition, was governed by a water-dwelling creature, a taniwha.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Could Gen Z Free the World From Email?
description: “It’s actually crazy how outdated it is.” People born after AOL Mail was invented seem to prefer to communicate in almost any other way.
content: Despite the reasonable qualms of older generations, Generation Z — generally defined as people born between 1997 and 2012 — is pioneering the return of chaotic trends like low-rise jeans, pop-punk and Ed Hardy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When a Preacher Doesn’t Credit His Sources
description: Ministers and a rabbi discuss “Sermongate” in the Southern Baptist Convention.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 10, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 10, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about Pope Francis’s surgery misstated Francis’s age when he became pope. He was 76, not 78.
source.name: The New York Times
